And so basically, in essence, bad teachers coming to poor school districts and better teachers going to suburban school districts.
And the question that's been put to those leaders is, okay, what are you going to do about it?

Both enterprises seem to be failing in the marketplace.
Ford's sales were down almost 20 percent in the past year, and according to Gallup, approval of the Iraq War has fallen 18 percentage points in the past year.
Both are clearly in the midst of restructuring efforts.
Since last fall, Bush has fired his defense secretary, who was the war's chief operating officer and replaced him with a respected outside executive, Robert Gates.
Bill Ford fired himself as CEO and hired a respected outside executive from Boeing named Alan Mullally as his replacement.
And at both companies, the change at the top didn't really replace the executive who was ultimately responsible for things.
Bill Ford is still the chairman of the board, and George Bush, of course, is still president.
And, you know, one of the things I liked in your essay was that both of them have very similar re-branding strategies.
They have almost the exact same re-branding strategy.
Ford unveiled what it called its way forward, and almost exactly a year later, President Bush unveiled what he called the new way forward in Iraq.
And I guess, you know, underlying this, the most important aspect in comparing the two is performance.
It's performance, but it's also the way that the failure to deliver on promises has really eroded their credibility.
Bill Ford - throughout 2005, Ford was undergoing a restructuring.
And he kept on promising, you know, we're going to have these profits and we're going to turn it around, and then every few months had to back away from it.
